Phillippe -- he's very bright, he's perceptive, but he is in such turmoil --
You grow fond of him.  That's good.
Don't play God with me, Aramis I -- Athos interrupts himself as he glimpses the naked Porthos moving across the courtyard toward the barn.
Go on.
But -- what is Porthos doing?
Going into the barn naked -- or so it appears. We INTERCUT Porthos in the barn with Aramis and Athos in house...
Porthos, alone within the barn, finds a thick plow rope a fashions a noose.
Now.  You were saying?
But -- what is he doing?
About to hang himself, I should think.

Porthos throws one end of the rope over the central beam the barn, and ties the other end off.  He shoves a milkin stool up below the noose, climbs onto it, and fits the no around his neck.  NOTE: When we see him in full view it i only from behind -- and this angle is a sight to behold.
Aramis' detachment only aggravates Athos' excitement.
Hang himself?!
He's threatened to do it, it's been building up in him for months.
We must stop him!
Come now, Athos, if Porthos is determined to end his life, then he will certainly manage to find the opportunity.
But -- but -- Athos jumps up and makes for the door -- but Aramis' hood helpers, at a signal from Aramis, bar his way.
Porthos, grave with drama, utters his last words...

A'dieu, cruel life!  Farewell to useless Porthos! He steps off the stool. His great weight drops.  The rope snaps taught.  The beam is tied to snaps like a twig -- right in the place where has been sawn nearly in half already. Porthos falls unencumbered and slams butt first into the floorboards of the barn, cracking them.
can hear the crack from where they're sitting.
I sawed the main beam in half.
The chain reaction has just begun.  The broken floorboard buckle, and the barn's walls, deprived of their central support, fall in on each other.
Athos and Aramis watch wide-eyed as the whole barn comple collapses around the unfortunate Porthos.  Athos gives Ar a look.
I'm a genius -- not an engineer! They jump up and run out.  The commotion draws others too especially the three wenches Porthos had been trying to b

It's a tangle of debris -- and from the size and weight o the pile, it looks as if no one could live through the collapse.  For a moment the whole pile lies silent; then suddenly it bursts apart and Porthos emerges, exploding w anger.

Aramis!!  You did this, didn't you! You knew I would try hanging myself, and you sawed the beam!  Admit it! Admit it, by God!!  ADMIT IT!!! Porthos' eyes are bulging; he's terrifying in his fury. he holds one of the broken barn's timbers like a giant cl ready to bash in Aramis' brains.  Aramis is totally casua
Well of course I knew it, Porthos. Porthos stands there, blinking.
You've been moping for months.  Now that you've gotten the idea of killing yourself out of the way, you can stop boring me and start being useful to me.  Now get some rest.
Well... Well... Okay. Porthos starts back toward the house.  Then one of the serving girls, heading back inside, sees in one of the up windows -- the face in the Iron Mask.  She SCREAMS --

Phillippe shies back from the window now, but it's too la everyone has seen him.  Aramis, with cold intellectual curiosity, quietly observes the women's reaction, even as hooded helpers scurry from the shadows to calm the fright locals.
Poor Phillippe!
The mask is terrifying... especially when unexpected.  Do you notice?
All I noticed was that Phillippe feels even more like an animal. Athos hurries in; Aramis looks at Porthos.
See, Porthos -- secrets are hard to keep.  We don't have much time.
Athos enters to find Phillippe in a corner of the bedroom slumped and ashamed in the darkness, holding the mask.
I've worn this mask so long, I couldn't sleep without it.

I will sit with you.  I can't sleep either. Athos settles into a chair, as Phillippe lays the mask as on the table and closes his eyes.  Athos looks toward the flames of the fireplace, and in their dancing shadows he the face of Raoul.  Phillippe's voice interrupts --
Athos...?  Thank you for being my guide... back into the world. Athos had not thought of it that way.  Phillippe closes h eyes again, and falls asleep.
Light falls on Athos' face; it is dawn.  He hears the whi of horses, and looks out the window to see a carriage abo to leave.  Reacting quickly, he hurries out quietly.
Aramis and Porthos are already loaded into the carriage, Athos runs up.
Where are you going?!
Paris.  There is still much to do. We'll be back soon.  Be ready.
But Aramis -- !  Phillippe can learn in time, but --
He can learn to be Phillippe in time.  But first he must learn to be Louis, and for that he has two more days.
What you're asking is impossible!
I offer you the perfect revolution. A revolution without bloodshed, without any loss of life, even without treason, for he too is the son of the King.
But --

You said you'd do anything, Athos, anything to replace this King.  So do it. Aramis motions to the driver, who snaps the reins and dri the horses away. Athos, wide-eyed and alone, watches the carriage roll awa He turns back toward the house, and see's Phillippe looki out the window -- without the mask.
Athos and Phillippe are having breakfast.
No, wait, do not hold your goblet that way.  With a king it is... so. He shows him, pinching the goblet between thumb and forefinger, as the other three fingers extend daintily.

It is not to be dainty.  Servants have touched the King's goblet, so he will touch it as little as possible. Phillippe tries it and the goblet slips from his fingers, crashing onto his plate and spilling onto everything.
I am so sorry!  Forgive me, I --
No!  Do not be sorry!  Never be sorry!  The King cares for nothing and for no one!  There are no mistakes when you are King!  What you do is right for every person!  A King has contempt for everyone!
Is that the king of king you wish me to be?  Or do you say this because of your son?
How did you know -- ?
Porthos told me. For a moment Athos can say nothing; then he shoves back f the table and storms from the room.
Athos is pacing in his room, all alone, rehearsing the th he wants to say to Phillippe.

I am not... I am not angry with you. You understand?  Good.  Now, as to acting like a king, we wish you to be a good king.  But at first... at first you must pass as Louis, and Louis is cold and cruel.  So you must stop looking at people with such softness.  It is... not Kingly. The eyes of a King say that all he cares about is himself, and your eyes -- how do I tell him this -- ? You eyes... ask so much.  You shouldn't care about me, about my -- about... Athos' voice breaks, his body sags.
Oh Raoul, my son... my son... Athos weeps.
Phillippe sits alone in the parlor; he looks up as Athos his face washed, no sign of grief -- marches in.
Come, we have much to do.

-- They practice sword fighting, Athos being sure that Phillippe knows Kingly posture... -- They rehearse holding court, with Athos showing Philli how to sit in a chair like a King on his throne, and then Phillippe trying it, with Athos then playing the roll of courtesan paying homage... -- They rehearse courtly dancing; and as they stumble, bo of them feeling embarrassed and ridiculous, they laugh.

Aramis' carriage rattles to a stop, the hooves of the hor sounding hollow on the cobblestones.  They are near the s area where the riots occurred; now, at night, everything looks deserted.  Aramis steps from the carriage.
Coming?
What use am I?
We go someplace dangerous.
Why didn't you say so? Porthos steps out with him, and Aramis leads the way down dark, spooky alley.
They walk through the murky darkness of Paris' backstreet
It is good to be out on a mission again... We are out on a mission, aren't we? Aramis grunts non-committally, lost in thought.

You're right.  Tell Porthos nothing. He needs to know nothing, for he is useless. Just as he says this a sinister form steps from the shado and blocks their way.  He holds a knife.  Another ROBBER a sword rises from a doorway beside them.
Your money or your life. Aramis looks bored; Porthos stands blinking in surprise. Then a third robber steps up behind them, cocking a pisto
Make it quick, old man!

Old?  Old?!  You're all trying to rob us because you think we're old? The man with a sword steps forward to hack Porthos down, Porthos spins, slapping the pistol, making it BOOM but mi he kicks the swordsman in the groin, then smashes his hea against the alley wall; he backhands the gunman.  The rob with the knife tries to run; Porthos snatches a barrel fr the street and hurls it into the fleeing robber's back; h falls in a heap. Porthos' fury has just begun.  He picks the fallen gunman by the throat, slams him stomach down across a broken all cart, and with one sweep of his mighty hand Porthos snatc down the man's pants.
Old?!  I'll show you old!! Porthos snatches the pistol from the cobblestones.  We se the shock and terror on the robber's face as he feels something shocking happen behind him.
Let's see you rob somebody with your pistol there!
Come on... Aramis, acting as if nothing happened, leads Porthos away
I have to tell you something.  I love Paris! Aramis has found what he's looking for:  a filthy brothel
Here we are. Aramis leads Porthos inside.
Sleazy whores lounge around, women at the very bottom of life.  They stir and try to look more appealing as the tw well dressed gentlemen enter.
Aramis... These are... these are whores!
So was Mary Magdalene, and our Lord loved her.
Did she have tits like that? A greasy, disgusting PIMP shuffles over.
What do you want?  White?  Black? Both?
No.  We want you, Father Belles. The pimp reacts with fury, drawing a pistol.
Get out!  Now!  I will kill you where you stand! Aramis slowly falls to his knees, before the pimp.

Bless me, Father, for I have sinned. The pimp -- the former Father Belles, the same man we saw the priest who prayed with the Queen at the royal birth i the opening -- shoves his pistol at Aramis' face.
Don't!  Get out!

I have sinned.  And no other priest's assurance of forgiveness can mean as much as yours.  Tell me that I can be forgiven, no matter what I have done. Aramis' eyes are hypnotic, staring deep into the fallen priest's soul.  Porthos is bug-eyed, certain Aramis' head about to be blown apart.
He's going to kill you, Aramis.
Then let him kill me, if all my faith is wrong. He stares at the pimp.  The pimp's finger trembles on the trigger.
I have come to help you make it right.  I have come to take you home. The pimp shakes convulsively; he drops to his knees, bows head, and weeps.
Aramis' carriage rattles through the dark streets; we pla these secret movement sequences with an ominous, Jack-the Ripper quality.  The carriage pulls into...
The priests scurry out to meet it.  First Aramis emerges, then Porthos -- but the appearance of the pimp surprises cathedral priests.  They cross themselves.
Father Belles! Crossing themselves, they embrace the prodigal priest; on MONK kneels before Aramis.
You have made a miracle!
God makes miracles.  You make dinner. As Aramis strides toward the dining room, a Jesuit hurrie to him.
The ball has been rescheduled -- for tomorrow. As Aramis hears this in surprise --
The carriage thunders through the countryside, back towar the manor house.
Athos and Phillippe sit at a table in the shade of a tree the table is a model of the palace which Athos is using t drill Phillippe on the palace's layout.
These rooms are yours.  Up these stairs -- or through this hidden passage -- is the room of your mistress... Michelle.
Whose rooms are those?
Your mother's. They are interrupted as the carriage bearing Aramis and Porthos clatters in.  Aramis is out immediately.
Change the horses!  Clear out everything!  NOW!!
The three Musketeers, plus Phillippe, are hurrying back toward Paris.
Aramis, this will never --
Louis is planning a visit to the Vatican, then who knows where after that.  If we miss him now we may not get another chance.
But --
It presses us but it is good for us too!  Louis' whims make him more vulnerable.  We are less ready, but so are his guards!
D'Artagnan, unready?
At a ball, everyone watches the King!
But what if something extraordinary happened?  Something so unusual that all the attention went to someone else?  Someone whose confirmation of Phillippe the King would never be questioned.
Who?
The Queen Mother.  Anne. And Aramis leans forward to tell them his plan...

Teams of servants are filing in and out of the palace wit food and flowers, decorating the ballroom for the ball th evening.  In contrast, Anne and her devout retinue of nun move in single file toward the garden chapel.
The nuns kneel at the altar as Anne enters the confession
Bless me Father, for I have sinned.
So have I. He slides open the partition window between them.
Father Belles -- ?! He taps a silencing finger to his lips.
They told me you were dead.

I was.  I see you are still a woman of faith.  I have come back to ask you if you believe that one lie can poison your whole life... and one truth can put it back together again. Anne stares at the eyes of the priest, back from hell.

As Louis' tailors outfit him in a dazzling gold peacock costume, complete with a jeweled mask at the end of a wan he amuses himself by looking out the window at the beauti young women arriving early for the ball.
It shall be interesting tonight. D'Artagnan enters, looking concerned.
Your Majesty.  This ball, with an open invitation to the nobility of Paris -- we have no way of checking --
You will protect me as you always have, d'Artagnan. Through the window Louis sees more beautiful young women.
By the way, Claude -- inform Mademoiselle Beaufort that she will be moving from her rooms -- He looks up to see that Michelle has entered through the door behind him.

Never mind, it seems we have already told her. But Michelle's appearance brings him up short.  It is not cruel brush-off; she is already harshly different:  her e are red from crying, her lips are tight in anger.
Murderer!  Murderer! She holds a letter, crushed in her hand.

I wrote Fromberge!  Under your seal! I wrote as you, demanding to know why he disregarded my order to keep Raoul from danger!  He writes back: "But your Majesty!  Your last letter ordered me to put him in front of the cannon!" She hurls the crumpled letter into his face.  Everyone is frozen, silent.  She staggers toward Louis as if to attac him, then falls to her knees, weeping.  No one helps her. Except d'Artagnan.  He kneels, hugs her shoulders, helps to her feet, and guides her toward her room.  But d'Artag looks back once, toward Louis.
Hysterical woman.
Sire, misuse of the royal seal -- !

She'll be gone tomorrow. As d'Artagnan and Michelle move out, they pass Anne, comi in.  Anne and d'Artagnan exchange a look; he remembers to give her a respectful nod, but she moves past, into the King's dressing room.  Louis is surprised.
Mother -- ?
May I speak with you?  Alone?
I am preparing for a ball!
We haven't visited in three years. And we should have privacy. Exasperated, Louis waves his attendants away.
What is it, mother?
I wish to discuss your brother.
He is dead!  By God's choice!  There is nothing to discuss.
First they told me he had died at birth.  Then your father admitted he was alive, but well cared for, in secret.  But the message that told of his death said he had been a prisoner.
I am King, Mother!  And I do not wish to discuss this with you.
He was my blood -- and I demand to know what happened to him.
Why would you ask now?  You never asked before!
Because I have dreamed of him.  Not as the baby they took away, but as a man.
You have prayed too much.  Your mind is weak. Avoiding her stare, Louis lifts a plaster bust of his fat its eyes like the sightless pupils of Greek gods.

I believe in dreams, Louis.  They are our souls speaking to us, from that world beyond our eyes.  And that son I never saw in daylight was standing in the moonlight of my dreams.  And he wore an iron mask. We see her from a low angle, from a POV behind Louis -- a we see the plaster bust burst upon the marble floor.
It -- it doesn't matter, Mother!  He is dead now!  Dead!
Yes.  Dead.  Two nights ago.  The night of my dream. And the night of Louis' "dream."  Anne begins to walk out
If... if he was wearing an iron mask in your dream, then how could you know he was your son? Louis smiles; he thinks he has her.
Then you did do it, Louis.  You did put your brother in an iron mask. All the blood is gone from Louis' face.  Anne walks from room, past Louis' waiting tailors.  He snaps at them.
I have a ball to attend! They rush in.  As they scurry about, dressing him in gold Louis' composure returns; he stares at himself in the gol mirror, likes what he sees... and smiles.
Aramis' carriage pulls off the road and into the trees. Musketeers and Phillippe pile out, to find another much grander carriage there waiting.  Aramis ushers them into
Whose carriage is this?
It was mine.  But since you are about to be the king, it is yours. The new carriage lurches away.
are bundles of elaborate clothes.
Phillippe first. They begin to dress Phillippe in a masquerade costume.
Remember, Phillippe... nobility is born in the heart.
Hold your goblet with two fingers.
And make love as if you don't care. The way Kings do.  And fart whenever you wish. Aramis tucks a note into Phillippe's pocket.

Remember, all you have to do is get through tonight.  Smile and nod a lot, and if you get stuck just wave and announce, "Continue."  In the morning you hand this note to d'Artagnan, pardoning Athos and instructing that he, Aramis and Porthos be brought to the palace as your advisors.  And all is well. Phillippe nods; everyone's nervous.  Aramis grabs more clothes and hands them out.
Now the rest of us.
Carriages disgorge guests, wildly attired for the masquer ball.  Porthos' carriage pulls in among them.

A magnificent masquerade ball is in full swirl; the dazzl light of chandeliers bounces off the gilt ceiling and sparkles on the jewels of swirling dancers, their numbers multiplied in the polished mirrors that line the walls. The King is dancing and laughing with sexy young ladies. D'Artagnan stands to the side of the ballroom, ever watch ever remote. As the dancers swirl, each one wearing a distinctive mask the garish style favored by the French nobility of the 1600's, we see one particular couple -- a large man, with excessively large woman.  They are dancing vigorously, an they take a break behind a huge pillar, they lift their m enough for us to see that the man is Aramis, and the "wom is Porthos. From the folds of their elaborate costumes they both with replicas of the iron mask that Phillippe once wore.
D'Artagnan watches everything.  We have to be lucky.

We will make our own luck tonight... if Phillippe holds up. Aramis peers across the ballroom, to where Athos and Phillippe mix among the revelers, using thin sticks to ho broad masks to their faces.  Behind the masks we see thei eyes -- Athos' intense, Phillippe's nervous and darting.
Stay calm, you're doing fine. Then Phillippe's eyes go strangely still; he sees, for th first time in his life, his twin brother, the King.

My brother... Louis dances the minuet, prancing as if he is the center the universe; but this bliss is broken when one of the dancers who swirls by him -- it is Aramis -- lifts the baroque outer mask he's wearing and reveals an iron mask beneath. The King staggers, stopping.  The sight stuns him, confus him; he looks around but the wearer of the mask has disappeared among the weaving patterns of dancers.  Louis hands dart to his eyes:  are they playing tricks on him? Seeing his reaction, Phillippe whispers --
He knew.  He knew what they did to me. The YOUNG BEAUTY dancing with Louis notices him falter.
What is wrong, your majesty?
Nothing, I -- continue. Louis rejoins the dancing... and then sees, on the balcon above him, a different person -- a huge "woman," Porthos who lifts off an outer mask to reveal an iron mask below.
There!  Do you see it?

See what, Majesty? Porthos has slipped away from the railing when the King l back up; the young beauty sees nothing, and turns back to King with a look that questions his sanity. D'Artagnan notices the King's reaction -- though he did n see the glimpse of the iron mask -- and is just as baffle everyone else when the King turns and staggers away.
Your Majesty...?

... tired.  Must... lie down. The music splatters to an awkward stop; Louis hurries out leaving his partner abandoned in the center of the ballro with everyone staring as if she just ruined the party.
Carry on, everyone... The music begins again, and the party goers, not knowing else to do, politely continue. Athos draws Phillippe away from the ballroom, into a side corridor.

head_text.subj: AT THE FOOT OF THE STAIRS TO THE BALCONY

text: Porthos waddles down stairs, and meets Aramis.
Quick, to the passages. They hurry in the same direction Athos and Phillippe went
D'Artagnan catches up to the King as he is entering the d of his royal apartment.
Your Majesty, is there anything -- ? The King shuts the door in d'Artagnan's face.
The King falls upon his bed, pressing his hands to his he
The three Musketeers and Phillippe move quietly up a stai and to the door of a room.  Phillippe whispers...
The room of the King's favorite mistress?
She will be at the ball.

The door opens and they move in; it is in fact empty, tho a mess.  They move to the wall, where Aramis, after a lit looking, locates the levers to open the wall/door to the King's secret passageway.  Aramis enters first, the other follow.  We half expect Michelle to pop up at any moment, the Musketeers enter the passage without incident.
Aramis silently leads the others through the secret passa to the portal into the King's bedroom.

The King is lying on the bed; we see him from the POV of someone approaching him slowly, silently.  When his eyes in panic, it is too late... We see Aramis, Athos, Porthos from the KING'S POV as they swarm him.
It is Judgment Day. His fist drops into frame... Louis loses consciousness.
as consciousness returns.  He see Phillippe in Louis' clothes.  Aramis, Athos and Porthos bow and say...
Your Majesty. LOUIS, still on his bed, now wears Phillippe's clothes.
Wh-- Wha--
Don't look so shocked, Phillippe. Come, you're going back to prison.

Phillippe?!  Why do you call me -- Now Louis understands everything.  He tries to struggle, instantly Porthos shoves a rag into his mouth. Aramis opens the main door a crack, and sees d'Artagnan h entered his room down the corridor, through whose open do he can guard the approaches to the King's rooms.  Aramis shuts the door again and turns to the others.
D'Artagnan guards the hallway!  You must go back the way we came! Athos puts his hands on Phillippe's shoulders.

Now, your Majesty.  It is time. Aramis and Porthos bow again to Phillippe -- now dressed looking exactly like the King.  Phillippe's mouth is dry; swallows hard, and follows Athos up the hidden stairs.
Athos and Phillippe move to the door; they stop there, an Athos adjusts Phillippe's costume one more time.
You know the way. Phillippe nods, tremendously nervous.

You have your note? Phillippe pats his pocket, like a boy being sent off to h first day at school.  He surprises Athos, hugging him.  T Phillippe opens the door and walks slowly down the hallwa Athos stands at the door and watches him go, all alone. Athos whispers, though Phillippe can't hear...
You have the heart of a king. Reluctantly, he shuts the door behind Phillippe.
as he conducts himself through the ornate corridor, down gilded staircase... and into --

Phillippe enters the ballroom, and the reappearance of th "King" draws new attention.  Everyone in the dazzling ballroom seems to stop and look straight at Phillippe. Phillippe freezes.  Stares, everywhere, stares!  For what seems an eternity, he can't move. But then he raises his hand and says --

Continue. As if by magic the music plays, the dancing resumes. Phillippe moves to the throne and takes his place upon it He seems to have made it; people glance -- dancing ladies young Musketeers, old advisors -- but no one gives him a second look.  For a moment, Phillippe feels safe. And then he sees Michelle, her eyes glassy and riveted up him.  She wears her most beautiful gown -- the first one Louis gave her -- but one shoulder strap dangles sloppily Her lips and cheeks are awkwardly rouged, her hair is mus she is drunk.  She weaves her way to him and curtsies elaborately.

My gracious noble lord... Phillippe's heart is pounding; he looks around for help. can only guess who this woman is.  The advisors have now noticed her; Claude quickly dispatches orders to keep the party going along, and waves guards over.
How are you... Michelle? She doesn't react, so he must have guessed right; but Phillippe knows nothing of what happened just before the ball, and he's ambushed by her anger.
How should I be?  I came to give this back to you. She starts tearing off her dress.  Claude and the guards reach her; the young Musketeers grabbing her.
Fret not with this, your Majesty -- But Michelle fights, slapping, clawing -- and when one of young Musketeers grabs her from behind, his arm to her throat, Phillippe jumps up.
Stop!  You're hurting her! Phillippe's face shows something Louis' never did: compassion.  He looks into Michelle's eyes.

However I have wronged you I will make amends.  Whatever the cost. Phillippe could not have said anything more unlike Louis; everyone who heard the remark -- Claude, the guards, and especially Michelle -- stare at him in frozen amazement. Phillippe realizes his blunder; they've caught him. The MUSIC STOPS.  But the attention is not directed at th throne; all eyes shift to the main doorway, where Anne ha appeared.  She is indescribably beautiful; she wears a br gown, her hair is brushed and bejeweled, she radiates the light of a woman who felt old at thirty and who has discovered, at forty, that she is more stunning than ever Her arrival draws even more attention than the reappearan of the King; everyone watches transfixed as she approache Phillippe sees her -- his mother.  He stands on legs that seem to have no bones.  His mother. She moves to him, her eyes filling with tears.  When she almost to the throne, Phillippe falls to his knees before and kisses her hand. No one can believe it, not from this King.  Yet the momen strikes them as beautiful, and they applaud happily. Phillippe and the Queen Mother rise, and guide each other depending on each other for support, to a seat, he on the throne, she on a seat the servants place beside him. Phillippe gives a wave.

Continue. The ball continues, the music exuberant.  Michelle wander away, like a blind lamb.  Phillippe and his mother sit si by side, holding hands, their reunion passing in private between their clasped hands, and glistening in their eyes
Michelle, alone and forgotten, staggers down the corridor toward the King's rooms; she passes d'Artagnan's open doo
are tidying everything up; they have Louis gagged and tru up hand and foot, his eyes flashing hatred.

Don't worry, your Majesty.  We have a prison for you, where you can rest peacefully. Porthos drapes Louis over his shoulder, and they move int the passages.  Just as they close the portal behind them, door opens and Michelle wanders in like a zombie.  Sudden d'Artagnan is at her shoulder.
Michelle -- Then he sees the room is empty; he thought Louis was here
Where is he?
In... the ballroom.  But he isn't the same man.
As a minuet ends, Claude raises his glass in a toast.
To King Louis!  And to Anne, the Queen Mother! The guests applaud and reach for wine glasses; servants present Phillippe and Anne with champagne, and they sip -

To King Louis, and the Queen Mother! Everyone drinks; Phillippe suddenly remembers to hold his glass in his fingertips -- and it slips through his nervo fingers, hitting the floor with a crash. Dead silence; everyone is looking.  Then Anne drops her g too -- and everybody does it, as if to break the glass is part of the celebration. As the music begins again, Anne leans to Phillippe --
I retire now.  Wait two waltzes, then retire to your room; and spend the night in safety.  We have much to talk about, and have the rest of our lives to do it.
Good night, Mother.
Good night... my son. She kisses him on the cheek; it brings tears to both of t She moves to the door, everyone bowing as she leaves.
Anne encounters d'Artagnan.  He stops, so taken by the si of her that no one seeing them could miss that he loves h
Anne!  You look -- Remembering himself, he bows deeply.
My Queen...
D'Artagnan. She takes his hand, not caring who is watching.
I have never seen a sight more beautiful than you, tonight.
We have much to discuss.  Tomorrow. She moves off, toward her room.  D'Artagnan enters the ballroom.
D'Artagnan sees "Louis" sitting on the throne.  More baff than alarmed, he grabs one of the Musketeer guards near h
How long has the King been back?
Some while, Captain.
He didn't pass my doorway, I was in my room.
He must've, Captain, there is no other way here. D'Artagnan stands and thinks; his mind begins to spin.

sees d'Artagnan, staring at him... then calling more guar over and giving them quick instructions; the guards hurry away.  Then d'Artagnan moves to Phillippe, and bows.  He looks at him carefully, but seems to see nothing unusual.
Continue.
Sire, we have an emergency -- of security.  I must ask you to accompany me.
... The ball... Continue.
I must insist, Sire. Phillippe stands, and follows d'Artagnan from the ball.

Aramis, Athos and Porthos -- carrying Louis -- descend th secret passages to the foundations of the palace, into a drainage channel leading to the river. They have stashed a boat there; they plop Louis into it a climb in themselves.  They row toward the archway that is exit to the river; the moonlit waters of the Seine glow outside, like a beacon of safe escape. But the steel grate of the archway slams down just before they reach it, and blades point at them from every angle the darkness.  A shielded lantern rises and its wick is turned up, revealing
he stands with a small contingent of young Musketeers.  H eyes are intense, his face in agony.
My friends. The only one they can see it d'Artagnan.  They all look a each other, in the small circle of light from the lantern

Only we four, the most trusted Musketeers, knew about the passages, meant to keep the King safe... Your Majesty... Phillippe steps out of the darkness; his eyes are full of shame and failure as he looks at Athos, but still he hold on, trying to maintain the charade that he is Louis.
Yes...?  Why do you bring me here, d'Artagnan?
The King!  Look!  It's the King! He means Phillippe.
Then who is that lying beside you? Porthos turns and looks at Louis -- then reacts as if he' totally surprised at the presence of this man tied up and gagged beside him.
Wh-- ?  Where did he come from? Athos grabs d'Artagnan's arm.
If you ever loved me -- if you ever loved honor, or anything else -- then stand now, and let it happen.

I cannot, Athos.  Dearly as I love you, I cannot. D'Artagnan takes his dagger and cuts the ropes that bind Louis' hands, and the gag that has kept him from talking. Aramis suddenly backhands Louis, knocking him flat on his back in the boat, and pointing to him -- Louis.
This man is an impostor.  We caught him trying to impersonate the King, and were just getting rid of him. Louis struggles upright.
D'Artagnan, arrest them all!
Shut up, knave! Aramis slaps Louis again, and pleads with his eyes that d'Artagnan accept their ruse.  D'Artagnan is dying inside

Before I came here, I insisted the King come with me.  The real Louis would never have let me insist. Seeing they are about to be arrested, the old Musketeers the boat spring into action against their younger counterparts.  Athos swats one swordsman with an oar; Por seizes the guard who has grabbed a hold of the boat and flings the man back into two of his comrades; Aramis grab Louis by the hair and puts his dagger to his throat.
Pull them back, d'Artagnan.
You can't do it.
Pull them back!
Everyone back.
Phillippe, get into the boat.  Into the boat!  Now! Phillippe obeys.
Open the gate. D'Artagnan nods to his men, and they open the iron gate leading out to the river. The boat makes for the opening.  Just as it is about to r it, Louis forces Aramis' hand.

You will not shed royal blood! He kicks at the boat and struggles to stand, making the b tip wildly and throwing everyone in it all around.  Arami draws the dagger away from Louis' throat to keep from kil him, and d'Artagnan makes a grab at Louis and drags him o the stone floor of the channel. The boat is almost through the opening -- and Louis snatc at his brother, Phillippe. The current outside the gate is rushing by, and the boat already caught in the current; it's pulling away and the Musketeers can't stop it.  Athos seizes Phillippe's legs tries to hold him, but the pressure of the current is gre and now not only Louis but some of the young Musketeers a helping hold Phillippe. Phillippe's legs slip out of Athos' grasp, and the boat flashes downriver... Aramis, Porthos and Athos have escaped... but Phillippe i captured, looking into the hate-filled eyes of his twin brother Louis.

Louis is angrily climbing through the passageways, back u into the main floors of the palace, venting his emotions d'Artagnan, just behind him; the young Musketeers with Phillippe, their prisoner, follow along further back.
I want all these passages sealed! Another stupid idea of my father's! Seal them all, every one!
It shall be done, your Majesty.
Even the bedchamber passages!  Let none remain!
Yes, your Majesty. They reach a doorway, and the King bangs through it, into own bedchamber, still spouting anger.
I was told this impostor was dead!
... You knew you had a double?

He is my brother. D'Artagnan is frozen in surprise.  Phillippe and his guar move into the room; seeing him in full light, wearing Lou own clothes, fans Louis' anger; he jumps forward and begi ripping the royal garments off Phillippe. D'Artagnan forces himself between Louis and Phillippe.
I -- I thought he was but... an impostor who resembled --
My twin.  Which has kept him alive. Until now.
No!! They whirl to see the Queen Mother, who has entered throu the main door.  She hurries to the space between her sons hugging Phillippe, then trying to hug Louis.
Louis, please -- !
My guards are useless!  Take her from me! He motions to the young Musketeers to restrain her; reluctantly they grip the arms of the Queen Mother.
What had you to do with this, Mother?
He is your brother!
He is nothing now. Louis draws a sword from the scabbard of one of the young Musketeers -- but d'Artagnan steps between him and Philli
Your Majesty... This man before you... He is royal blood, the same as you.  To spill it is the one thing even you cannot do.  It is against the laws of God, and of France.
Get out of my way.
Not once have I ever asked anything for myself.  I ask now.  Forgive this man, this prisoner... your brother.
Forgive?!

Aramis, Porthos and Athos too.  I know what they have done was a threat against you -- and yet that threat has been removed, with no harm coming to your Majesty.  If their passions were in error, their spirits have ever been noble. Forgive them.
They have plotted against me!  Me! The embodiment of God's will! D'Artagnan sinks to his knees before the king.

Your Majesty... Every day of your life, I have watched over you.  No angel could have stood a more faithful vigil.  I have bled for you, and have prayed, every day, to see you become greater than your office, better than the law.  Show me now what my faith and blood have purchased.  Show mercy. The words cut into everyone:  Anne, Phillippe, the young Musketeers.  But Louis' eyes are cold, as he responds --
You take the side of traitors?

Please, may I speak?  M'lord... I beg that you kill me.  I release you, before Almighty God, from any claim of sin in taking my life.  In fact I will pray that God reward you for your mercy to do it.  But do not -- I beg you -- return me to the prison, where I have lived so long. Phillippe's plea makes Louis pause... then smile.
D'Artagnan, you will hunt down Aramis, Porthos and Athos, and bring me their heads, or I will have yours.  And as for you, Phillippe... Back to the prison you shall go, and into the mask you hate.
No, Louis!  No!

Wear it until you love it.  And die in it!! Anne screams, and Louis waves to the guards, who draw her from the room, as d'Artagnan sags, on his knees before th King he has served so faithfully. Slowly, Phillippe lowers his head.

D'Artagnan returns to his bare room; he sits down upon th bed and drops his face into his hands. Then he hears the sound, like a SCREAM, but short and muffled, almost like the whelp of a kicked dog.  He lifts head sharply; where did that sound come from?  He is almo too tired, too sad, to investigate. Then the King, already shaken by the night's events, hurr into d'Artagnan's room.
What was that sound?!  Did you hear it?  It came from Michelle's room!
D'Artagnan enters, ahead of Louis.  They see nothing unus and d'Artagnan moves up the hidden stairs toward Michelle apartment.
D'Artagnan enters the room, and finds it empty -- but the window is open.  He moves toward it...
The King is pacing as d'Artagnan reappears.
Where is Michelle?
There. He points to the window.  Louis shoves open the drapes an leaps back in horror.  Michelle has hanged herself outsid Louis' window, the golden bunting of her bed tied as a no around her neck.

Anne has changed; she is tormented, but alive with energy pacing.  There is a knock at her door, and the old nun op it to d'Artagnan.  The old nun leaves them alone; d'Artag moves to Anne and takes her hands, to look into her eyes.
There were two.  Not one.  But two.
I couldn't tell you.  You had enough to carry.

Anne... The night we had together... I always wanted more.  But that one, it was enough.  Enough to make me love you forever.  I want you to remember that... and go on.  As strong as you are now.  No matter what happens. He kisses her.  She drinks in his love.  Then he stands a moves to the door.  He looks back, then stares out.
D'Artagnan -- ? He looks back once more; he seems to want to tell her something; but whatever it is, he can't find the words, a with a last loving look at her, he walks away.
A sudden visual, establishing the Bastille, the horrific legendary prison of Paris.
Phillippe, his head covered in a burlap hood, is rushed through the twisting stairways of the prison.

location: A CELL, IN THE BOWELS OF THE BASTILLE

text: The guards remove the hood, and Phillippe sees the cell. Then he sees the blacksmith there, with a new iron mask, his eyes take on a fresh horror.
No.  Please!  No! The guards seize him and the blacksmith places the mask o Phillippe's face, as he screams.  They seal the mask with small padlock, whose key is distinctive, and jeweled.

The two guards and the blacksmith are coming downstairs a completing their work.  Far above them, in the prison tow the cries of the prisoner echo; he sounds like a raving madman now. The two guards and the blacksmith enter an office at the of the tower; the BASTILLE JAILER looks up.
Pay me quick, I want out of here. Soldiers, swords drawn, appear in the doorway behind them
What --

You saw the prisoner's face. Understanding, the blacksmith raises his hammer toward th soldiers; but he is stabbed in the back by the jailer, an the soldiers skewer the two guards who helped him.  A sol lifts the jeweled key from the hand of a dead guard.
is handed to the King by Andre, the young Lieutenant.  Lo hangs the key around his own neck, with a thin gold chain
Now.  Where is d'Artagnan?
Out directing the search for the traitors.
When he returns, watch him.  When he leaves again, you tell me. The Lieutenant bows.  Louis smiles, and fingers the key.

Squads of young Musketeers gallop along the river, and through the dark streets around it, searching... ALONG THE BACK WALL OF NOTRE DAME CATHEDRAL, three forms scurry through the darkness:  Aramis, Porthos and Athos, heaving, wheezing.  They duck into a niche of the wall to avoid capture from another patrol galloping by.  Then Ara unlocks a door in the cathedral wall and they stagger in.
The three Musketeers struggle through the catacombs, reac the chapel, and fall gasping to the floor.
Bloody hell...
We can't... stay here.  That traitor d'Artagnan... knows about this place.
Can we eat... before we go?  This excitement's given me an appetite.
Bread and wine... in that cupboard. Porthos hauls himself to his feet and turns up the wick o the lantern.  The rising light reveals a note, stuck to t cupboard with the blade of a dagger.
A note.  Pinned with a dagger, like the old days. He removes the note, and reads...

"Phillippe has been removed to the Bastille, to the lower dungeon.  At midnight tonight I will order the guard changed, and will delay the replacements for ten minutes.  That should give you ample time.  Never have I needed more to say:  One for all, and all for one.  D'Artagnan."
He lures us to capture.
He seeks redemption.
You're a fool!
Perhaps.  But of d'Artagnan I am certain.  What he did tonight was what he told us all along he would do -- be faithful to his King.
So what has changed?
Perhaps he serves a different king.
What choice is there?  If Phillippe is in the Bastille, then to the Bastille we will go.
You are right.  But it is a trap.
So what?  I'd rather die covered in blood, than an old man, lying in my own piss.
Then to the Bastille.
To the Bastille.  And death.

The stone walls rising into the Paris night seem to ooze evil.  The building looks impossible to get into, much le get out of; its doors appear to be solid blocks of wood, encased in stone ramparts. We hear a sharp, echoing KNOCK; Aramis, Athos, and Portho stand outside the main entrance, Athos slumped between th other two like a beaten captive being delivered to jail. No one answers their knock; the three Musketeers exchange doubtful glance, and Porthos knocks again.  A guard insid slides open a view port of the massive door.
Open up!  We have a prisoner! The port shuts, bolts rattle, and the great door heaves o The Musketeers glance at each other again, and play their roles, Aramis and Porthos dragging Athos inside.
The prison courtyard is murky in the darkness, and ringed doors leading into mazes of corridors to its dungeons.
Take him down to level three.  The Captain will see to the documents. Aramis and Porthos drag Athos into one of the shadowy por surrounding the courtyard.
The three Musketeers duck into the inky shadows; Aramis c the bonds that hold Athos' hands, and gives him the extra sword he had beneath his cloak.
It worked!

It's a prison, you idiot!  They don't expect anyone to try getting in!  The problem will come when we want out! Aramis shushes them, and leads them into another quiet corridor.  They hear the distant bells of a church, then suddenly they must scramble, as a platoon of guards carry torches troop up stairs into the corridor; the Musketeers dart like rats into dark nooks; as the guards pass, the Musketeers huddle, and the bells end their tolling.
Midnight!  We have ten minutes! They press on, deeper into the Bastille.

Anne moves to the window, where she starts to kneel for h nightly prayer; but she stops.  Outside in the garden, fa below her window, is d'Artagnan on horseback, waiting.  T eyes connect.  He has a single rose in his hand.  Never taking his eyes from her, he places the rose on the stone bench of the garden, and reins his horse away. Then she understands what he was trying to tell her befor in the hallway; it was goodbye.
D'Artagnan rides away quickly, passing -- without seeing Lieutenant Andre, who has been watching him.
Through the night d'Artagnan gallops.  We see his destina in the distance:  the Bastille.
The great gates of the palace swing slowly open, and out a whole platoon of young Musketeers, surrounding Louis himself, on horseback and dressed like a soldier.

The three Musketeers scramble down a flight of stairs, through another corridor, down another stairway.  They pa cells; wretched prisoners look up, but none of them is Phillippe.  Then the Musketeers surprise a JAILER.
Hey...! But before the man can say anything else, Porthos has cru him like a bug against the wall.  They rip the huge ring keys from the jailer's waist, and take his torch.
He lies on the floor; he sees the light of a torch, comin him like sunrise... and then he hears a voice --
Phillippe...?
How did you -- They open the door and release him -- from the cell, but from the mask.  He tries to hug Athos. They head back the way they came.
Louis and his platoon of young Musketeers ride through th streets, scattering the paupers who sleep there.
Back up the stairs... through one corridor... they start the second flight of stairs, then stop and scramble back.
(whispering) Someone's coming! They take cover on either side of the corridor, and lift their swords.  It's a man coming down the stairs, with a hooded lantern... they raise their swords to strike --
D'Artagnan!
The way is blocked above.  The Captain of the Bastille has turned back from the mission I sent him on, and is in the courtyard with a party of men.
He lies.  He is here to trap us.
I came to see you safely out.  Check for yourself. Porthos climbs the stairs to check; D'Artagnan looks at Phillippe, in the mask.
All you have suffered, I would gladly have borne myself, to keep it from you. Athos spits on the floor, in derision.  But Porthos comes barreling back down the stairway.
D'Artagnan is right, the courtyard is filling with soldiers!
This way. He leads them quickly down a side corridor; the others ha no choice but to follow.

D'Artagnan leads them around another corner, into a long corridor; at the end of it is a massive door.  They reach and d'Artagnan produces a set of keys marked with the roy seal of the Musketeers; he begins unlocking the three padlocks that secure the door.
Once you are through, don't stop until you reach the river.
They will know you helped us, if we go this way.
That doesn't matter now. They open the door... and as they do they see Louis and h platoon of young Musketeers arriving outside.
There!  Stop them!

Betrayed! The young Musketeers serving the King jump from their hor and grab for the door; but d'Artagnan leaps forward, his sword flashing.  After a second of surprise, Athos, Arami and Porthos jump forward too, and there is a brief, blood skirmish at the door.  But the young Musketeers have overwhelming numbers, and firearms too; protecting Philli the old Musketeers draw back inside and succeed at pullin the door shut and latching it quickly.

Back the way we came! They race back up the corridor -- the four Musketeers, an Phillippe, in the iron mask -- and turn the corner.  They reach another inner door, pass through it -- and see the soldiers of the Bastille coming at them.

Back! They retreat, and Porthos slams the second door.  Like al the inner doors of the Bastille, it's heavy wood, a foot thick, and Porthos seals it with a huger iron bar.  But there's nowhere else to run.

Trapped. At the far end of the corridor, the King's young Musketee have the same keys to the outer door that d'Artagnan did, they are breaking through.  Louis and two dozen of his personal bodyguard pour through the door.

Charge them! The young Musketeers obediently charge down the corridor. Stepping up shoulder to shoulder -- Aramis, d'Artagnan, Athos, Porthos -- the four veteran Musketeers meet the charge, first with pistols, then with swords, a wall betw Louis' men and Phillippe.  The battle in the cramped conf of the corridor is bloody and fierce; the young attackers only get a few men into the fight at any one time, and th who step before the famous veterans are cut down. Louis' young Musketeers retreat, to regroup.

head_text.subj: AT LOUIS' END OF THE CORRIDOR

text: Louis is furious, jumping at Lieutenant Andre, who has dragged a wounded comrade back from the fight.
Cowards!  Twenty run from four?!
The corridor nullifies our number... And no one has stomach to fight the Captain. Louis is disgusted by this loyalty -- and he has a soluti
D'Artagnan!

head_text.subj: AT THE OTHER END OF THE CORRIDOR

text: Louis' voice echoes down to the veteran Musketeers and Phillippe, in the Iron Mask.

I am not angry with you.  I knew you would lead me to them, and so you have!  Lay down your sword, and I will not punish you!  I will let you retire in peace -- to live out your days in the countryside!  And I will give your friends a swift execution, if you surrender now. The words bounce down the long corridor; then silence. D'Artagnan stands holding his sword, staring away from hi friends, toward the King and his gang of young Musketeers
D'Artagnan.  Perhaps you should accept his offer, for we are dead anyway.

He is right, d'Artagnan. Athos says nothing; but when d'Artagnan looks at him, he lowers his eyes in shame for ever having doubted d'Artagn loyalty and friendship. Phillippe speaks up, from behind the Iron Mask.
Wait.  Bargain me to Louis, for all your lives.  You have done your best.  Let me go, and let all of you find peace.

No.  Even if I could give up my friends, I could never give up my son. This hits them like a bombshell -- and suddenly it all ma sense; d'Artagnan's loyalty to Louis, his dogged hope tha could somehow influence him toward goodness.  We see thei stunned faces, each in turn:  Athos, Aramis, Porthos, and Phillippe.

I never had any idea you existed... until they found you.  And in all that time, I never had a moment's pride as a father -- until now. D'Artagnan and Phillippe embrace, lost father to lost son From the heavily barred door to their rear comes a powerf pounding; the Bastille's soldiers are trying to break it down.  Time is running out. Aramis looks back down the corridor toward the door to th outside, barred now by Louis and his young guards, their muskets bristling like spikes; and yet that way is the on possible hope for escape to the outside.
D'Artagnan... Those are young Musketeers down there.  They have been weaned on our legends.  They revere us -- it is an advantage. Why don't we charge them?

I trained those men myself.  They will stand and fight.  But if we are to die, let it be this way. He draws his sword and points it into the air.  Aramis li the tip of his sword to join that of d'Artagnan.  Porthos does too... and then Athos joins them.
One for all.  All for one.

If I could have a blade, then I would be please to run with you. D'Artagnan gives Phillippe a dagger.  They look at each other.  Then d'Artagnan begins to scream.  The others tak the shout.  Then they step around the corner, and charge.

head_text.subj: THE LAST CHARGE OF THE MUSKETEERS

text: We film it in all its glory, a visual feast:  the Last Ch of the Musketeers.  Their capes swirl about time, their h flies, their legs take on new life. At first the young Musketeers at the end of the corridor frozen in surprise; their youthful Lieutenant is awed by dashing, beautiful bravery of the thing.
Magnificent valor...

Shoot them!  Shoot them! Louis grabs a musket from one of the reluctant soldiers a fires:  SSSBOOM!  With the first explosion of gunfire the others pull their triggers; the powder in their weapons flashes and crashes... The musket balls fly down the hallway, sparking off the s walls and floor, ricocheting, punching holes through the capes and flesh... but still the Musketeers charge like t young men they once were -- still are, in spirit. In the confines of the Bastille's stone corridor the nois deafening, and the space in front of the guards is filled with the dense gray smoke of the gunpowder.  None of them see anything beyond it... and all is quiet.

Draw blades! The King's Guards draw their swords, and wait; are all th old Musketeers dead? Slowly the figures emerge from the smoke -- in SLOW MOTIO walking now, no need to run.  All are wounded, but all ar still alive. The Four Musketeers, along with Phillippe, move slowly an steadily toward the blades of the young Guards; a fight t the death?  So be it. But the young Lieutenant will have none of it; as one of men lifts a sword to plunge it into the chest of d'Artagn the young Lieutenant bats the sword down, with his own.

Stop! He steps forward toward d'Artagnan; but instead of thrust his sword he salutes with it. His men follow suit, saluting and bowing to the courage o these men they have grown up wanting to follow. King Louis, for the moment, is frozen. D'Artagnan looks back at Phillippe; he has bullet holes i two different places at the edges of his clothes, but he unwounded. Then d'Artagnan sees Louis, with his long dagger, leaping Phillippe.
D'Artagnan throws himself between the two twins and hurls Louis backwards, then spins to Phillippe.
Phillippe!

I am unhurt -- Louis bounces off the wall and thrusts back again, drivin the blade into d'Artagnan's back. D'Artagnan's face jolts; he staggers, his legs buckle. D'Artagnan falls into the arms of his friends. Louis stands holding his bloody dagger, everyone staring him:  d'Artagnan, the old Musketeers, the young ones.
You!  Vicious... evil...! He leaps into Louis, overwhelming him in fury, wrenching dagger from his brother's hand and gripping his throat.
Phillippe...!  No... Don't... He is your brother! Phillippe releases Louis, who falls, choking, gasping. Lieutenant Andre is surprised by what he just heard.

Brother...? Phillippe darts to d'Artagnan, being cradled by Athos; At lifts a hand from d'Artagnan's back; it is drenched in bl D'Artagnan is dying. Athos, Aramis, Porthos... none of them can speak.  They g d'Artagnan, as if through their will alone they could kee his life from leaking away.  The young Musketeers stand transfixed, watching their legendary Captain die.  Philli sags; his voice from behind the iron mask is torn by grie
All this time... I was a lost secret.  But you were hiding all your loyalty, all your love.  You were the Man in the Iron Mask.
D'Artagnan...

Shhh.  All my life, this is the death I have wanted.  To die among you.  One for all... and all for... He is gone. Phillippe rises with a slow, terrible resolve, and moves Louis.  When Louis tries to rise to his feet he finds the blade of the young Lieutenant Andre pointed at his chest.
All my life, all I ever wanted to be... was him. He points to d'Artagnan.  Phillippe rips away the key tha dangles around Louis' neck.

where the soldiers of the BASTILLE'S COMMANDER are finall breaking through; working the massive door aside they fin THE KING with his guards, and Aramis, Athos, Porthos, alo with their prisoner, in the Iron Mask.
We have recaptured the prisoner.
No, no!  I am your -- A blow in his chest from the Lieutenant stuns the prisone and drops him to his knees.  The King orders the BASTILLE
You will put this madman where no one can hear his insanity.  Let him be fed by a deaf mute.  But feed him well, and let him have a long life within the Iron Mask.
And them? He means Aramis, Porthos, and Athos.
They are my loyal servants.
No!  No...! But the guards are dragging him to the deepest, darkest dungeon of the Bastille.

At the end of a lane of elms, where the markers of king's graves stand clustered, royal workmen place a mighty marb monument stone above the final resting place of d'Artagna Athos, Aramis, Porthos, and the King -- Phillippe, known King Louis now -- stand gathered there, as Aramis in his priest's garments utters the funeral incantations.  Arami voice breaks as he does so.  Porthos' eyes pour out river tears.  Athos' grief is beyond weeping. Phillippe holds the arm of his mother.  She holds the ros d'Artagnan left her.
Amen. Athos moves up between Aramis and Porthos, and links them with his arms.
He was the best of us all. Aramis and Porthos move off together, to walk the lane of elms; Athos remains by the grave, unable to leave. Phillippe pats Anne's arm.
I will be with you in a moment, Mother. She too moves down the lane of trees, touching the tip of rose pedals to her lips as the tears run down her face. Phillippe moves up to Athos.

After all you have done, I must ask you one more service to your king. I have lost my father.  And you have lost your son.  Let me love you like a son to a father.  And I pray you live for this, to love me like your son. Athos can't speak; he can only nod yes.  Phillippe moves join his mother, leaving Athos to take one final look dow the grave.  Then as Athos moves off to join Aramis and Porthos, we PAN from the name "D'ARTAGNAN" on the stone, the pattern chiseled beneath the name. It is a mask, of iron.
